attributes.title: The Role of Input Quantity of Crosslinguistic Influence

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value:
The Role of Input Quantity on Crosslinguistic Influence
This is the second study of Faidra Faitaki's DPhil thesis on crosslinguistic influence (CLI) in English-Greek sequential bilingual children. While her first study investigates the role of linguistic (or typological) factors on CLI, the present study explores the role of input quantity factors. Both studies use the same measures (standardised tests and experimental language production tasks described above) but differ in terms of their population: the first study targets Greek children with English as an Additional Language (EAL) in the UK, while this study focuses on Greek children with English as a Foreign Language (EFL) in Greece. In both studies, the sequential bilingual participants are compared to age-matched monolingual Greek and English controls (25 participants per group are needed in the first study and, as mentioned above, 36 in the second study). Given that the design of both studies is identical, the monolingual data collected for the first study is also going to be used in the second study. As such, data collection for the present study has started but it is hoped that readers will consider this to be a valid pre-registration as data for the focal population (English-Greek sequential bilingual children) has not been collected yet.

other.value: It is possible that the data will be additionally analysed with Linear Mixed Effect Models (LMEs), using the lme4 package on R.

sample.value: A power analysis based on the findings of a pilot study indicated that 36 children are needed in each of the five groups (bilingual Greek-English children in submersion, Greek-English children in immersion, children in enhanced EFL, monolingual Greek children and English monolingual) in order to obtain 80% power at the 0.001 level. However, since participant recruitment is done through children's (pre-)schools, more than 36 participants might be interested to participate in the study. Additional participants who meet the inclusion criteria will be allowed to participate as an increased sample size will also increase the power.

analyses.value:
Children's age, gender and socioeconomic status will be reported in the descriptive statistics. Then, two sets of One-Way ANOVAs will be used in order to compare bilingual children's performance to the Greek monolingual and the English monolingual children in the two experiments (i.e. 2x ANOVA for Experiment 1 and 2x ANOVA for Experiment 2) . In other words, the results of the two experiments and the two treatments will be analysed separately because.
A further four One-Way ANOVAs will be used to compare bilingual and monolingual children's raw scores in the vocabulary and grammar measures in both languages (1x Greek vocabulary, 1x Greek grammar, 1x English vocabulary, 1x English grammar). 
Moreover, in order to explore the link between between participants' use of the linguistic structures and their lexical and/or grammatical knowledge. To explore this link, two sets of bivariate correlations (per treatment) will be conducted.

outliers.value: Outliers will be defined as observations with z-scores less than -3 or greater than 3. Observations that constitute outliers will  be removed. Participants' data will be excluded

dependent.value:
The provision of third person singular subject pronouns HE and SHE (Experiment 1) and subordinate clause marker TO (Experiment 2) will be tested using two experimental language production tasks. The provision of the target linguistic structures will be awarded with 1 point and their omission with 0 points.
In addition, children's lexical and grammatical knowledge will be measured using two standardised tests in English (the BPVS and the TROG), and two equivalent tests in Greek (the PPVT-R Greek and the DVIQ). These tests have not been standardised for a bilingual population, so raw scores will be used for both bilingual and monolingual participants in both languages.

conditions.value:
In addition to the experimental conditions outlined above, each experiment will feature a control condition. Under this condition, in Experiment 1 children will have to use full DPs (e.g. 'the teacher') instead of the subject pronoun, and in Experiment 2 children will have to use tensed verbs with third person singular marking (i.e. 'eats') instead of the marker TO followed by an infinitive in English or the subjunctive in Greek. Experiment 2 will also feature filler items (where children will not have to produce anything). All items in both experiments will be presented in a pseudo-random order.
Bilingual children will participate in the Greek and the English version of the experiments (the 'Greek treatment' and the 'English treatment'. The two versions will be presented in a counterbalanced order for each child.
The two experiments will also be presented in a counterbalanced order.

hypothesis.value:
Experiment 1: Greek-English successive bilingual children will use fewer overt subject pronouns in English than English monolingual children, and the same number of overt subject pronouns in Greek as Greek monolingual children.
Experiment 2: Greek-English successive bilingual children will produce the same number of infinitival marker TO in Greek and English as Greek and English monolingual children.

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

attributes.title: INTELLECT
attributes.description: – International Lower Limb Reconstruction Collaborative: A multi-centre audit on reconstruction following lower limb trauma

q1.value: INTELLECT – International Lower Limb Reconstruction Collaborative: A multi-centre audit on reconstruction following lower limb trauma

q3.value:
Open lower limb fractures can be devastating events, not only in the context of polytrauma, but also as isolated injuries. These can present with a wide spectrum of severity, depending on mechanism and energy involved. Due to the magnitude of these injuries, a multidisciplinary approach has been advocated, involving orthopaedic and plastic surgery teams.

For years, the Lower Extremity Assessment Project (LEAP) has been the best source of evidence for the management of open lower limb fractures. This consisted of a National Institute of Health-funded, multi-centre, prospective, observational study, including 601 cases, in 8 US-based major trauma centres. Their 2002 report4 helped better understand the prognosis of lower limb trauma and to compare reconstruction versus amputation in these patients. However, the LEAP study and recent efforts to standardise the management of lower extremity open fractures5 have failed to resolve the controversy regarding several aspects of the treatment of these injuries. Some of these include: timing for the reconstruction6, flap type selection, strategies for bony fixation, antibiotic protocols, selection of recipient vessels and postoperative monitoring and flap training protocols. Furthermore, even for features that consensus has been reached, compliance with these standards has been variable among different units.

Trauma is a global concern, and its burden is greater in developing countries. The aim of this study is to attempt to resolve outstanding queries left by LEAP and later studies, along with identifying aspects in which consensus has been already reached, and aspects that future studies should address.

q4.value: This is a retrospective audit looking at the management of open lower limb fractures. Due to its descriptive nature, no hypothesis have been proposed by the authors

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We are planning to conduct an international, multi-centre, retrospective audit of patients with open lower limb fractures, gathering a set of core outcomes for open lower limb fractures. We will aim to capture a 24-month snapshot of current trends in practice in a series of international centres covering patients treated between the 1st January 2017 until 31st December 2018, allowing follow-up for at least a year. This audit will include all patients presenting to participant centres with open lower limb fractures. We aim to retrieve information regarding: type and severity of injuries; comorbidities and smoking status; timing for debridement and definitive soft tissue reconstruction; flap selection (free versus local and muscle versus fasciocutaneous flaps); type of bony fixation; antibiotics prophylaxis; flap loss rate, re-exploration rates; thromboembolism rates; postoperative infection rates; length of inpatient stay; time to full weight-bearing; non-union rates; osteomyelitis rates and time to return to work.

To coordinate this multinational project the International Lower Limb Reconstruction Collaborative (INTELLECT) in partnership with RSTN will identify key clinicians at trauma centres in the United Kingdom and overseas. These will be responsible for seeking approval for local audits as per their national legal frameworks and will be responsible for supervising data collection. We will encourage trainees and medical students (contributors) to gather data for this study using well established models developed by the RSTN. A coordinating team at the Surgical Interventional Trials Unit (a Royal College of Surgeons supported trials units in Oxford) will coordinate collection of anonymised data using the GDPR-compliant REDCap software.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
Through RSTN, BAPRAS and the University of Oxford, invitations will be sent to major trauma centres in the United Kingdom and all over the world. Every centre that agrees to participate will be included in this study.

Senior clinicians in each participating centre will independently register this audit as per local protocols. Suitable cases will be identified by reviewing local databases and data will be collected in parallel for each centre.  Once the data gathering exercise has been completed on each centre, data will be collected centrally.

Study Participants
Records concerning patients admitted with a lower limb open fracture will be reviewed and included in this audit

Inclusion Criteria
•	Patients with open lower limb fractures
•	Male and female patients
•	No age restriction

Exclusion Criteria
•	Patients who were assessed at the participating centre, but that definitive treatment was performed in a different hospital

q13.value: As a retrospective audit of practice no strict sample size calculations have been done

question.value:
1.	Type and severity of injuries

2.	Comorbidities and smoking status

3.	Timing for debridement and definitive soft tissue reconstruction

4.	Flap selection trends: 
a.	Free tissue transfers versus local flaps
b.	Fascio-cutaneous versus muscle free flaps

5.	Type of bony fixation

6.	Use of antibiotics

7.	Active involvement of plastic and orthopaedic surgeons, or not

8.	Short term outcomes
a.	Flap loss rate
b.	Re-exploration rates
c.	DVT rates
d.	Postoperative infection rates
e.	Length of inpatient stay

9.	Long term outcomes
a.	Time to full weight bearing
b.	Non-union rates
c.	Osteomyelitis rates
d.	Time Return to work

10.	PROMs

Statistical analysis will be performed in compliance with the STROBE guidelines for observational studies14. Demographic differences between centres will be measured using chi-square tests. Outcome variations between centres will be appraised using unadjusted funnel plots and multivariate binary logistic regression models will be used to obtain odds ratios accounting for the impact between variables and outcomes.

q25.value:
As per NHS Health Research Authority guidance this study is not considered to be research, but an audit. Therefore, no formal ethics approval is required for centres in the United Kingdom.

Participation in this project will be acknowledged in resulting publications. Members of the INTELLECT collaborative will be considered co-authors in any PUBMED-indexed resulting publications. A maximum of 2 senior clinicians, per each recruiting centre, will be acknowledged as co-authors for their role as guarantors of the information collected under their supervision. Medical students and postgraduate trainees will have to submit a minimum of ten cases to the INTELLECT database in order to be considered co-authors.

registration_responses.q1: INTELLECT – International Lower Limb Reconstruction Collaborative: A multi-centre audit on reconstruction following lower limb trauma
registration_responses.q3:
Open lower limb fractures can be devastating events, not only in the context of polytrauma, but also as isolated injuries. These can present with a wide spectrum of severity, depending on mechanism and energy involved. Due to the magnitude of these injuries, a multidisciplinary approach has been advocated, involving orthopaedic and plastic surgery teams.

For years, the Lower Extremity Assessment Project (LEAP) has been the best source of evidence for the management of open lower limb fractures. This consisted of a National Institute of Health-funded, multi-centre, prospective, observational study, including 601 cases, in 8 US-based major trauma centres. Their 2002 report4 helped better understand the prognosis of lower limb trauma and to compare reconstruction versus amputation in these patients. However, the LEAP study and recent efforts to standardise the management of lower extremity open fractures5 have failed to resolve the controversy regarding several aspects of the treatment of these injuries. Some of these include: timing for the reconstruction6, flap type selection, strategies for bony fixation, antibiotic protocols, selection of recipient vessels and postoperative monitoring and flap training protocols. Furthermore, even for features that consensus has been reached, compliance with these standards has been variable among different units.

Trauma is a global concern, and its burden is greater in developing countries. The aim of this study is to attempt to resolve outstanding queries left by LEAP and later studies, along with identifying aspects in which consensus has been already reached, and aspects that future studies should address.

attributes.title: Inter-rater reliability and concurrent validity of ROBINS-I: protocol for a cross-sectional study

q1.value: Inter-rater reliability and concurrent validity of ROBINS-I: protocol for a cross-sectional study

q2.value: Maya Jeyaraman, Rasheda Rabbani, Nameer Al-Yousif, Reid Robson, Leslie Copstein, Jun Xia, Michelle Pollock, Samer Mansour, Mohammed T. Ansari, Andrea Tricco, Ahmed Abou-Setta

q3.value: I confirm this study has been granted in-principle acceptance.

registration_responses.q1: Inter-rater reliability and concurrent validity of ROBINS-I: protocol for a cross-sectional study
registration_responses.q2: Maya Jeyaraman, Rasheda Rabbani, Nameer Al-Yousif, Reid Robson, Leslie Copstein, Jun Xia, Michelle Pollock, Samer Mansour, Mohammed T. Ansari, Andrea Tricco, Ahmed Abou-Setta
registration_responses.q3: I confirm this study has been granted in-principle acceptance.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: The effects of major depressive symptomatology on audiovisual integration capacity and visual ensemble perception

other.value:
To participate in this study, participants must have normal or corrected-to-normal hearing and vision.

Due to an administrative mix-up, a few participants have already been tested at this point. However, we have NOT had access to any of the data, and as such this is a valid pre-registration.

sample.value: GPOWER (Erdfelder et al., 1996) was used to calculate a required sample size for this experiment using an observed correlation found in Wilbiks and Beatteay (2019) of r=.398 and using an alpha of .05 with a power (1-β) of .9, the recommended sample size is 58 participants. Initially, 58 participants will be recruited, while continuing to recruit and replace those participants who produce unusable data.

analyses.value:
Pearson correlations (or alternative correlations, depending on assumption tests) will be run between capacity estimates, PHQ-9 and CUDOS to determine the relationship between depression symptoms and audiovisual integration capacity. Correlations will also be run between Navon, PHQ-9 and CUDOS to investigate whether increased depressive symptomatology is associated with a local precedence bias
Within participant ANOVAs using speed as the independent variable and capacity as the dependent variable, will be run to assess whether capacity for integration increases with slower speeds of presentation.

outliers.value: Participant data will be excluded if responding approaches chance, falling within a 95% confidence interval around chance responding (0.5).

dependent.value: The key dependent variables will be audiovisual integration capacity (which will be measured with an audiovisual integration task as used by Wilbiks & Dyson (2016;2018), and global precedence in perception, which will be measured with a Navon (1977) task.

conditions.value: All conditions in this experiment will be within subjects. All participants will be asked to complete two self-report questionnaires regarding the presence and severity of depression symptoms, the Navon task, and a task specific to audiovisual integration capacity.

hypothesis.value:
What is the relationship between the capacity for audiovisual integration and increasing severity of major depressive disorder symptoms? We expect to find that there is an effect of depressive symptomatology and these tasks, but based on conflicting findings in previous research we are unsure if it will be a positive or negative relationship. 

We are also investigating the relationship between the presence and severity of depression symptoms and global versus local precedence bias, and expect to find that more severe symptoms are associated with more local precedence in visual perception.

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

Due to an administrative mix-up, a few participants have already been tested at this point. However, we have NOT had access to any of the data, and as such this is a valid pre-registration.

Correlations will also be run between Navon, PHQ-9 and CUDOS to investigate whether increased depressive symptomatology is associated with a local precedence bias
Within participant ANOVAs using speed as the independent variable and capacity as the dependent variable, will be run to assess whether capacity for integration increases with slower speeds of presentation.

What is the relationship between the capacity for audiovisual integration and increasing severity of major depressive disorder symptoms? We expect to find that there is an effect of depressive symptomatology and these tasks, but based on conflicting findings in previous research we are unsure if it will be a positive or negative relationship.

q2.value: Zachary Mohr, Jaclyn Piatak, Suzanne M. Leland, Jared McDonald

q3.value: This is a replication of an earlier project described on EGAP (registration http://egap.org/registration/5462 ).  The second hypothesis was found to be not significant and there was some concern that this might have been driven by the way the question was worded. We have clarified in the questions who Mr. Johnson is in the scenario and asked the question about blame to the prisoner more clearly.

q4.value:
•	Blame Attribution Theory
o	H1a: Individuals will place less blame on the transport provider when the contractor is providing the service compared to the government.
o	H1b: Individuals will place greater blame on the guards when the contractor is providing the service compared to the government.
o	H1c: Individuals will place greater blame on the prisoner when the contractor is providing the service compared to the government.
•	Social construction / Worthiness / Deservingness
o	H2a: Individuals will place greater blame on the transport provider when an innocent bystander is killed compared to the prisoner.
o	H2b: Individuals will place more blame on the guards when an innocent bystander is killed compared to the prisoner.
o	H2c: Individuals will place more blame on the prisoner when an innocent bystander is killed compared to the prisoner.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a 2x2 experiment that describes a scenario where a prisoner escapes their restraints and kills someone. The first treatment is whether the prisoner is being transported by the government or a contractor. The second treatment is whether the person that is killed is another prisoner or a bystander.

q9.value: Simple random assignment into one of the four treatments.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Jared McDonald was working in the lab that collected the data as a part of a larger omnibus.  He didn't analyze the data as that is responsibility of the researchers (Piatak, Mohr, and Leland), but he did clean and label the data. He did not analyze the data and was not aware of the previous study. He was asked to analyze the data after the cleaned data was delivered to the researchers. We have not looked at the data.

question.value: This data was collected from students that participated in POLS Lab omnibus experiments that are taken online through the SONA research management system and collected by Qualtrics. The students are usually given some small incentive such as extra credit to participate in these experiments

q13.value: We are usually hoping to get 500 students.

q14.value: The primary driver of our sample size is the somewhat arbitrary constraint of students needing extra credit.

q15.value: The POLS Lab collects data over a specific time period and then stops students from being able to do the experiment so that the extra credit can be reported to their professors at the end of the semester.

question.value: 2x2 Treatment is prisoner killed v. innocent victim; and whether the transport was being run by the government or contractor
The primary outcome of interest is a 1-5 scale of blame for Department of Corrections, the contractor, Interstate Transport Inc (when appropriate), guards, the prisoner, and the victim.
Appropriate bivariate tests of differences of means and multivariate models might include OLS or ordered logit

registration_responses.q2: Zachary Mohr, Jaclyn Piatak, Suzanne M. Leland, Jared McDonald
registration_responses.q3: This is a replication of an earlier project described on EGAP (registration http://egap.org/registration/5462 ).  The second hypothesis was found to be not significant and there was some concern that this might have been driven by the way the question was worded. We have clarified in the questions who Mr. Johnson is in the scenario and asked the question about blame to the prisoner more clearly.
registration_responses.q4:
•	Blame Attribution Theory
o	H1a: Individuals will place less blame on the transport provider when the contractor is providing the service compared to the government.
o	H1b: Individuals will place greater blame on the guards when the contractor is providing the service compared to the government.
o	H1c: Individuals will place greater blame on the prisoner when the contractor is providing the service compared to the government.
•	Social construction / Worthiness / Deservingness
o	H2a: Individuals will place greater blame on the transport provider when an innocent bystander is killed compared to the prisoner.
o	H2b: Individuals will place more blame on the guards when an innocent bystander is killed compared to the prisoner.
o	H2c: Individuals will place more blame on the prisoner when an innocent bystander is killed compared to the prisoner.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: Simple random assignment into one of the four treatments.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11: Jared McDonald was working in the lab that collected the data as a part of a larger omnibus.  He didn't analyze the data as that is responsibility of the researchers (Piatak, Mohr, and Leland), but he did clean and label the data. He did not analyze the data and was not aware of the previous study. He was asked to analyze the data after the cleaned data was delivered to the researchers. We have not looked at the data.
registration_responses.q13: We are usually hoping to get 500 students.
registration_responses.q14: The primary driver of our sample size is the somewhat arbitrary constraint of students needing extra credit.
registration_responses.q15: The POLS Lab collects data over a specific time period and then stops students from being able to do the experiment so that the extra credit can be reported to their professors at the end of the semester.
registration_responses.q8.question: This is a 2x2 experiment that describes a scenario where a prisoner escapes their restraints and kills someone. The first treatment is whether the prisoner is being transported by the government or a contractor. The second treatment is whether the person that is killed is another prisoner or a bystander.
registration_responses.q12.question: This data was collected from students that participated in POLS Lab omnibus experiments that are taken online through the SONA research management system and collected by Qualtrics. The students are usually given some small incentive such as extra credit to participate in these experiments
registration_responses.q16.question: 2x2 Treatment is prisoner killed v. innocent victim; and whether the transport was being run by the government or contractor
registration_responses.q17.question: The primary outcome of interest is a 1-5 scale of blame for Department of Corrections, the contractor, Interstate Transport Inc (when appropriate), guards, the prisoner, and the victim.
registration_responses.q19.question: Appropriate bivariate tests of differences of means and multivariate models might include OLS or ordered logit

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Exploring intuitions and judgments about rarely punished rules: How punishment for “phantom rule” transgressions is opportunistically enforced

sample.value: A pilot study was conducted to approximate power needed to detect an interaction. The power analysis was conducted using PANGEA (Westfall:jakewestfall.org/pangea/) and it revealed that data from 180 participants will have 80% power to detect an effect size of d = .2.

analyses.value:
Our first test will be an analysis of variance (ANOVA) examining the effect of condition type and scenario type on punishment, blame, and moral scores, with follow-up tests using Tukey's method to compare differences between phantom rule only and phantom rule + social norm violation. 


If appropriate (based on model fit and conversion status), we will regress the indexed scores on condition type (phantom rule alone vs. phantom rule + social norm violation), and scenario type (6 scenarios), and their interactions in a linear mixed model that contains random intercepts for participants. Planned contrasts for will be assessed for condition type (phantom rule vs. phantom rule + social norm violation), as well as interactions with scenario type.

Though our blame and punishment items are all theoretically distinct. If they are all highly correlated, we will create an index from our blame and punishment items for clarity of reporting. 


If all scenarios individually show the same pattern of effects, we will also collapse scenarios into a single factor for clarity of reporting.

outliers.value:
Participants displaying non-variance in responses will be excluded from analyses. Missing values will be excluded on a trial-by-trial basis to preserve as much of our original sample as possible. 

We will also exclude participants who have cook's distances greater than 1 to see if the results differ, we will report the results without these participants if they do in fact influence regression results.

dependent.value:
Punishment & Blame DVs:

Punishment Police - How justified is it to be legally punished?
Punishment Monetarily - How justified is it to be fined?
Blame - How deserving of blame of the [phantom rule action]
Dichotomous Punishment - Imagine this person get stopped by the police, do you think they should get a ticket or that they should be let go with a warning?

Morality & Person Perception DVs:

Morally good or bad is this [person] 
Morally good or bad is [phantom rule action]
How competent is the person who committed the [phantom rule action] violation

Effect of Race DVs:

How likely is it that if YOU did this, someone would notice?
How likely are YOU to be legally punished for this action?
How likely are YOU to be financially punished for this action?

conditions.value:
There is one between-subjects factor (Rule Type) with two levels (Phantom Rule alone vs. Phantom Rule + Social norm). 

Participants will randomly receive one (either Phantom Rule alone or Phantom Rule + Social Norm) vignette (6 total scenarios) that describes breaking either the phantom rule alone or the phantom rule plus a social norm violation. These vignettes will be presented in completely random order to all participants, with no repeating scenarios.

hypothesis.value:
Phantom rules are operationalized here as legally codified rules that have norms that contradict following the law (e.g., jay-walking). Pilot work and Study 1 examined general beliefs about these unenforced laws, and how they differ from social norm violations and affect judgments. In this experiment, we aim to extend that work and explore how judgments about violations to phantom rules –codified laws that are rarely but selectively enforced– differ when alone compared to when they are paired with a social norm violation. 

Punishment and Blame
H1: We predict that "phantom rule" violations are seen as more punishable (legally and monetarily) when paired with a social norm violation
H2 : We predict that "phantom rule" violations are seen as more blameworthy when paired with a social norm violation 

Morality & Person Perception
H3: We predict that phantom rule violations paired with social norm violations will lead to worse perceptions of moral character 
H4: We predict that phantom rule violations paired with social norm violations will lead to worse judgments of moral wrongness for the action 
H5: We predict that individuals who commit a phantom rule violations alone (not paired with a social norm violation) will be perceived as less competent

Effect of Race
H6: We predict that individuals of minority racial status (Black, Latin, Asian, Other) compared to Whites will report that they themselves would be punished it that if they violate the phantom rule regardless of (i.e., collapsed across) the presence/absence social norm violation

If all scenarios individually show the same pattern of effects, we will also collapse scenarios into a single factor for clarity of reporting.

attributes.title: Expectation and Experience: What do meat eaters think about the taste of a plant-based burger?
attributes.description: The demand for animal protein is becoming more concerning due to its adverse effects on health, environment and animal welfare.  The majority of people in the UK are categorised as ‘high meat consumers’, suggesting dietary Green House Gas (GHG) emission is one of the big contributors of climate change (Scarborough et al., 2014). Therefore, many food scientists are putting effort to develop strategies to encourage consumers to have a plant-based diet (Smil, 2002). However, a change in eating habits can be challenging and met with resistance. This study aims to understand i) how meat eaters perceive plant-based foods, ii) what their expectations are of these sources and iii) how much their expectancy and experience is consistent in tasting a plant-based burger. To investigate these aims, we will recruit 72 participants from community members and students (UoB) and 48 participants will be meat eaters and 24 participants will be vegans and vegetarians. They will be randomly allocated into three conditions. Conditions will have the same food (plant-based burger) with different neutral descriptions. In condition 1, the burger will be labelled as ‘plant-based burger’ and meat eaters will be in this condition. In the second condition the burger will be presented as a ‘meat burger’ to the other 24 meat eaters. In the third condition, there will be no manipulation and vegans and vegetarians will be offered a plant-based burger labelled as ‘plant-based burger’.  Appetite ratings (liking, fullness and satisfaction) will be measured twice (expected and after eating) by using a standard 100mm Visual Analogue Scale (VAS).  There will a digital hand dynamometer as an additional measure to understand how eating affects acute strength. We predicted that participants in plant-based condition will report less enjoyment and less satisfaction compared to participants in meat burger condition. In addition, in plant-based burger condition, there will be a significant difference in expected liking and experienced (during eating) liking. Overall, this study will help researchers to develop new interventions to encourage consumers to eat more plant-based foods to reduce dietary GHG emission.
tags: Meat eaters vs. vegans and vegetarians

q1.value: Expectation and Experience: What do meat eaters think about the taste of a plant-based burger?

q3.value: The demand for animal protein is becoming more concerning due to its adverse effects on health, environment and animal welfare.  The majority of people in the UK are categorised as ‘high meat consumers’, suggesting dietary Green House Gas (GHG) emission is one of the big contributors of climate change (Scarborough et al., 2014). Therefore, many food scientists are putting effort to develop strategies to encourage consumers to have a plant-based diet (Smil, 2002). However, a change in eating habits can be challenging and met with resistance. This study aims to understand i) how meat eaters perceive plant-based foods, ii) what their expectations are of these sources and iii) how much their expectancy and experience is consistent in tasting a plant-based burger. To investigate these aims, we will recruit 72 participants from community members and students (UoB) and 48 participants will be meat eaters and 24 participants will be vegans and vegetarians. They will be randomly allocated into three conditions. Conditions will have the same food (plant-based burger) with different neutral descriptions. In condition 1, the burger will be labelled as ‘plant-based burger’ and meat eaters will be in this condition. In the second condition the burger will be presented as a ‘meat burger’ to the other 24 meat eaters. In the third condition, there will be no manipulation and vegans and vegetarians will be offered a plant-based burger labelled as ‘plant-based burger’.  Appetite ratings (liking, fullness and satisfaction) will be measured twice (expected and after eating) by using a standard 100mm Visual Analogue Scale (VAS).  There will a digital hand dynamometer as an additional measure to understand how eating affects acute strength. We predicted that participants in plant-based condition will report less enjoyment and less satisfaction compared to participants in meat burger condition. In addition, in plant-based burger condition, there will be a significant difference in expected liking and experienced (during eating) liking. Overall, this study will help researchers to develop new interventions to encourage consumers to eat more plant-based foods to reduce dietary GHG emission.

q4.value: * Meat eaters in manipulation  (plant-based burger will be labelled as a beef burger) condition will find the burger more pleasant and filling compares to meat eaters in control (plant-based burger will be labelled as plant-based burger) condition. They will also show more strength on hand dynamo meter compare to meat eaters in control group.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
This study used a double- blind, between subject and within subject design, with labels (‘beef burger’, plant-based burger’) as a between-subjects factor and time points (expected measures: pleasantness, fullness and satisfaction and actual measures meal enjoyment, fullness and satisfaction) as within-subject factors. Participants will be randomly allocated three equal-sized groups (‘no manipulation’ – meat eaters, ‘manipulation ‘– meat eaters and ‘no – manipulation’ vegetarians and vegans) with the constraint that there will be equal numbers of men and women in each group. 
There will be three menus (table 2) on the trays with the same burger (plant – based burger), (with a soft bun, salad leaves and ketchup) and there will be neural but different descriptions in each menu (the label/description of the burger will be the same for no deception meat eaters and vegetarians and vegans as the third group ‘vegetarians and vegans’ will act as a control group).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be community members who must i) be 18 or over, ii) have English as a first language or have an equivalent level of fluency iii) currently reside in the UK, iv) not have any significant food intolerances or allergies (including gluten) v) abstain from eating for at least 3 h before completing the study vi) be a meat eater ( for group 3, the study will be advertised as ‘The UK Foods Study 3’ where this requirement will be changed as ‘be a vegetarian or vegan’). They will be recruited through School of Psychological Science Experimental Hours Scheme and from Nutrition and Behaviour Unit volunteer participant data base.

q13.value: We aim to recruit 72 participants based on two similar studies.

q14.value: To determine sample size, we employed a similar study conducted by Schouteten et al. (2016), in which the authors measured the liking towards conventional versus plant-based burger in blind, expected and informed conditions (n = 97). Although this study design is similar to our design, it did not provide us baseline measures and effect size information to do a power analysis. Therefore, we decided to use another similar study conducted by Gumussoy (in preparation) in Nutrition and Behaviour Unit (NBU) laboratory. This study enables us to measure the changes in pre-lunch and post-lunch appetite and it provides enough information to calculate effect size. Based on this, the power analysis (G power) indicated that 22 participants (in total for two groups) across two groups had 80% power for detecting a large effect size when applying a 0.05 criterion of statistical significance. Since the effect size of this study is large (d = 0.65), we decided to be conservative and the research aims to recruit more participants than the calculated number to allow for possible drop - outs during the study. Additionally, although it was decided to have two groups (meat eaters – no deception and meat eaters – deception) in this study, to understand what vegan and vegetarians also expect from plant-based burger and how their experience would be after eating the burger, we decided to add another group (vegans and vegetarians – no deception) in our study. Therefore, this study will consist of three groups where 24 participants will be assigned to each group. The reason why we will recruit 24 for each group is we would like to round the number from 22 to 24 for in order to balance gender across groups.

question.value: Independent variable will be descriptions of the burger (plant-based burger or beef burger) that is also between-subjects factor that will allow us to make comparisons between three conditions in terms of pleasantness, fullness and satisfaction.

We will measure expected pleasantness, desire to eat, fullness and satisfaction. Also same dependant variables will be measured post-meal to make a comparison (within-subject) and to determine if there is an attitude -  behaviour gap.

The data for the various outcome (expected pleasantness, fullness and satisfaction; actual (meal enjoyment, fullness and satisfaction) will be analysed separately by using One-Way ANOVA, with one between-subject factor (descriptions) to understand differences between three groups.
A dependant t-test for paired samples will be used to explore if there is a difference between consumer attitudes (expected pleasantness, fullness and satisfaction) and behaviour (meal enjoyment, fullness and satisfaction).

attributes.title: The Impact of Student Loans on Enrollment, Attainment, Credit, and Earnings

summary.value: This project is a randomized controlled trial of the display of student loans in college students' financial aid award letters. Several thousand students will be randomized to be shown a status-quo letter that does not include the federal loans for which the student may be eligible or to one of two letters that include different amounts of these loans. Effects on educational attainment, borrowing, and employment will be assessed in the year of the intervention and subsequent years.”

registration_responses.summary: This project is a randomized controlled trial of the display of student loans in college students' financial aid award letters. Several thousand students will be randomized to be shown a status-quo letter that does not include the federal loans for which the student may be eligible or to one of two letters that include different amounts of these loans. Effects on educational attainment, borrowing, and employment will be assessed in the year of the intervention and subsequent years.”

summary.value:
PRE REGISTRO
Se espera que los tweets más compartidos van a ser los que se alinean con la identidad política del participante y contienen palabras de carga emocional.
Se espera que los tweets compartidos que tengan contenido emocional sean compartidos más rápido que los compartidos que no lo tengan.
Se espera que el reporte de los participantes de que sientieron y pensaron durante el experimento incluya descriptores emocionales (similares a los utilizados para categorizar los tweets)
